trans-unit.source: Setup a storage connection string
trans-unit.target: Setup a storage connection string

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage Client Library for .NET supports using a storage connection string to configure endpoints and credentials for accessing storage services.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage Client Library for .NET supports using a storage connection string to configure endpoints and credentials for accessing storage services.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you maintain your storage connection string in a configuration file, rather than hard-coding it into your application.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you maintain your storage connection string in a configuration file, rather than hard-coding it into your application.

trans-unit.source: You have two options for saving your connection string:
trans-unit.target: You have two options for saving your connection string:

trans-unit.source: If your application runs in an Azure cloud service, save your connection string using the Azure service configuration system (`*.csdef` and `*.cscfg` files).
trans-unit.target: If your application runs in an Azure cloud service, save your connection string using the Azure service configuration system (`*.csdef` and `*.cscfg` files).

trans-unit.source: See [How to create and deploy a cloud service](../articles/cloud-services/cloud-services-how-to-create-deploy.md) for details about Azure cloud service configuration.
trans-unit.target: See [How to create and deploy a cloud service](../articles/cloud-services/cloud-services-how-to-create-deploy.md) for details about Azure cloud service configuration.

trans-unit.source: If your application runs on Azure virtual machines, or if you are building .NET applications that will run outside of Azure, save your connection string using the .NET configuration system (e.g. `web.config` or `app.config` file).
trans-unit.target: If your application runs on Azure virtual machines, or if you are building .NET applications that will run outside of Azure, save your connection string using the .NET configuration system (e.g. `web.config` or `app.config` file).

trans-unit.source: Later on in this guide, we will show how to retrieve your connection string from your code.
trans-unit.target: Later on in this guide, we will show how to retrieve your connection string from your code.

trans-unit.source: Configuring your connection string from an Azure cloud service
trans-unit.target: Configuring your connection string from an Azure cloud service

trans-unit.source: Azure Cloud Services has a unique service configuration mechanism that enables you to dynamically change configuration settings from the Azure Management Portal without redeploying your application.
trans-unit.target: Azure Cloud Services has a unique service configuration mechanism that enables you to dynamically change configuration settings from the Azure Management Portal without redeploying your application.

trans-unit.source: To configure your connection string in the Azure service configuration:
trans-unit.target: To configure your connection string in the Azure service configuration:

trans-unit.source: Within the Solution Explorer of Visual Studio, in the **Roles**
trans-unit.target: Within the Solution Explorer of Visual Studio, in the **Roles**

trans-unit.source: folder of your Azure Deployment Project, right-click your
trans-unit.target: folder of your Azure Deployment Project, right-click your

trans-unit.source: web role or worker role and click **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: web role or worker role and click **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: ![Select the properties on a Cloud Service role in Visual Studio][connection-string1]
trans-unit.target: ![Select the properties on a Cloud Service role in Visual Studio][connection-string1]

trans-unit.source: Click the **Settings** tab and press the **Add Setting** button.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Settings** tab and press the **Add Setting** button.

trans-unit.source: ![Add a Cloud Service setting in visual Studio][connection-string2]
trans-unit.target: ![Add a Cloud Service setting in visual Studio][connection-string2]

trans-unit.source: A new **Setting1** entry will then show up in the settings grid.
trans-unit.target: A new **Setting1** entry will then show up in the settings grid.

trans-unit.source: In the **Type** drop-down of the new **Setting1** entry, choose
trans-unit.target: In the **Type** drop-down of the new **Setting1** entry, choose

trans-unit.source: **Connection String**.
trans-unit.target: **Connection String**.

trans-unit.source: ![Set connection string type][connection-string3]
trans-unit.target: ![Set connection string type][connection-string3]

trans-unit.source: Click the **...** button at the right end of the **Setting1** entry.
trans-unit.target: Click the **...** button at the right end of the **Setting1** entry.

trans-unit.source: The **Storage Account Connection String** dialog will open.
trans-unit.target: The **Storage Account Connection String** dialog will open.

trans-unit.source: Choose whether you want to target the storage emulator (Microsoft
trans-unit.target: Choose whether you want to target the storage emulator (Microsoft

trans-unit.source: Azure storage simulated on your local machine) or a storage
trans-unit.target: Azure storage simulated on your local machine) or a storage

trans-unit.source: account in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: account in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: The code in this guide works with either
trans-unit.target: The code in this guide works with either

trans-unit.source: option.
trans-unit.target: option.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can target the storage emulator to avoid incurring any costs associated with Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can target the storage emulator to avoid incurring any costs associated with Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: However, if you do choose to target an Azure storage account in the cloud, costs for performing this tutorial will be negligible.
trans-unit.target: However, if you do choose to target an Azure storage account in the cloud, costs for performing this tutorial will be negligible.

trans-unit.source: If you are targeting a storage account in the cloud, then enter the primary access key for that storage account.
trans-unit.target: If you are targeting a storage account in the cloud, then enter the primary access key for that storage account.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to copy your primary access key via the Azure Management Portal, see [View, copy, and regenerate storage access keys](storage-create-storage-account.md#view-copy-and-regenerate-storage-access-keys).
trans-unit.target: To learn how to copy your primary access key via the Azure Management Portal, see [View, copy, and regenerate storage access keys](storage-create-storage-account.md#view-copy-and-regenerate-storage-access-keys).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Your storage account key is similar to the root password for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Your storage account key is similar to the root password for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to protect your key.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to protect your key.

trans-unit.source: Avoid distributing it to other users or saving it in a plain-text file that is accessible to others.
trans-unit.target: Avoid distributing it to other users or saving it in a plain-text file that is accessible to others.

trans-unit.source: Regenerate your key using the Management Portal if you believe it may have been compromised.
trans-unit.target: Regenerate your key using the Management Portal if you believe it may have been compromised.

trans-unit.source: Select target environment
trans-unit.target: Select target environment

trans-unit.source: Change the entry **Name** from **Setting1** to a friendlier name
trans-unit.target: Change the entry **Name** from **Setting1** to a friendlier name

trans-unit.source: like **StorageConnectionString**.
trans-unit.target: like **StorageConnectionString**.

trans-unit.source: You will reference this
trans-unit.target: You will reference this

trans-unit.source: connection string later in the code in this guide.
trans-unit.target: connection string later in the code in this guide.

trans-unit.source: ![Change connection string name][connection-string5]
trans-unit.target: ![Change connection string name][connection-string5]

trans-unit.source: Configuring your connection string using .NET configuration
trans-unit.target: Configuring your connection string using .NET configuration

trans-unit.source: If you are writing an application that is not an Azure cloud service, (see previous section), it is recommended you use the .NET configuration system (e.g. `web.config` or `app.config`).
trans-unit.target: If you are writing an application that is not an Azure cloud service, (see previous section), it is recommended you use the .NET configuration system (e.g. `web.config` or `app.config`).

trans-unit.source: This includes Azure Websites or Azure Virtual Machines, as well as applications designed to run outside of Azure.
trans-unit.target: This includes Azure Websites or Azure Virtual Machines, as well as applications designed to run outside of Azure.

trans-unit.source: You store the connection string using the `<appSettings>` element as follows.
trans-unit.target: You store the connection string using the `<appSettings>` element as follows.

trans-unit.source: Replace `account-name` with the name of your storage account, and `account-key` with your account access key:
trans-unit.target: Replace `account-name` with the name of your storage account, and `account-key` with your account access key:

trans-unit.source: For example, the configuration setting in your config file may be similar to:
trans-unit.target: For example, the configuration setting in your config file may be similar to:

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to perform the how-to tasks in this guide.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to perform the how-to tasks in this guide.
